children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfæʃənd◂/  old-fashioned clothes, styles, words etc are no longer considered modern or fashionable, although some people still wear them or still use them:
examples: ▪ i don’t wear that skirt now - it looks so old-fashioned.
▪ ‘wireless’ is an old-fashioned word for radio.
▪ albert was a tall, gangling man with long blond hair, like an old-fashioned rock star’s.

children.name: dated
children.definition: /ˈdeɪtɪd, ˈdeɪtəd/  use this about clothes or styles that used to be fashionable, especially until recently, but now seem old-fashioned:
examples: lỗi thời
▪ just look at the hairstyles in this photo -- they’re so dated!
▪ the song was a big hit last year, but it’s already starting to sound dated.

children.name: be on the way out
children.definition: /biː ɒn ðə ˌweɪ ˈaʊt/  to be gradually becominglesspopularor common after having been very popular or fashionable:
examples: đang lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
▪ it was said that coal was on the way out and would be replaced by nuclear energy.
▪ when i was in highschool disco was already on the way out.

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfæʃənd◂/  old-fashioned opinions and ways of living were common in the past, but are not the way most people think and behave now:
examples: lạc hậu
▪ in those days, people believed that divorce was morally wrong, but this now seems very old-fashioned.
▪ he has some very old-fashioned ideas about women.

children.name: outdated
children.definition: /ˌaʊtˈdeɪtɪd◂, ˌaʊtˈdeɪtəd◂/  outdated opinions, methods, or systems are not suitable for modern times and need to be changed and made more modern:
examples: use in negative sentence
lạc hậu
▪ outdated laws and regulations are failing to keep crime on the internet in check.
▪ outdated textbooks, decrepit buildings, overcrowded classrooms - the list of problems is long and growing.
▪ the image of the civil service as a male, middle class bastion is now outdated.

children.name: traditional
children.definition: /trəˈdɪʃənəl/  traditional opinions, methods, or customs have existed for a long time, and have not been changed or affected by modern ideas:
examples: truyền thống
▪ the local people still use traditional farming methods which have been used for hundreds of years.
▪ the traditional idea that a woman’s place is in the home
▪ tom went to a very traditional boys’ school.

children.name: outmoded
children.definition: /aʊtˈməʊdɪd, aʊtˈməʊdəd/
examples: lỗi thời, cổ lỗ sĩ
outmoded belief/attitude/way of thinking etca way of thinking that was once popular but is not useful or suitable anymore:
▪ the views of many of the senior professors reflect outmoded concepts and ideas.
▪ the government’s outmoded attitudes are dragging the whole country back into the nineteenth century.

children.name: unfashionable
children.definition: /ʌnˈfæʃənəbəl/  abelief orattitudethat is unfashionable is no longer fashionable or popular:
examples: lỗi mốt, lỗi thời
▪ smoking has become very unfashionable in the last ten years.
it is unfashionable to do something
▪ it’s unfashionable these days to say you want to get married and give up your job, isn’t it?

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfæʃənd◂/  old-fashioned machines and equipment have a design that is no longer modern:
examples: lỗi thời
▪ he rides one of those old-fashioned bikes with high handlebars.
▪ a lot of the machines at the factory are very old-fashioned.
▪ old-fashioned ceiling fans have been making a comeback as a cheap and reliable alternative to air conditioning.

children.name: outdated
children.definition: /ˌaʊtˈdeɪtɪd◂, ˌaʊtˈdeɪtəd◂/  use this about machines or equipment that use old-fashioned designs, and should be replaced with more modern ones:
examples: lỗi thời
▪ it is hard to run a business with outdated equipment.
▪ a rebel army, equipped only with outdated russian weapons

children.name: obsolete
children.definition: /ˈɒbsəliːtǁˌɑːbsəˈliːt/  use this about machines and equipment that are no longer being produced, and that seem old-fashioned because newer machines have been invented which can do the job much better:
examples: lỗi thời ( không sản xuất nữa )
▪ the old 5¼ inch floppy disks are now obsolete.
make something obsolete
▪ a new type of ‘network computer’, which could make existing pcs obsolete within five years

children.name: antiquated
children.definition: /ˈæntɪkweɪtəd, ˈæntəkweɪtəd/  very old and old-fashioned and no longer suitable for modern needs:
examples: cổ, ko hợp thời
▪ my mother’s antiquated vacuum cleaner still works, believe it or not.
▪ hospitals suffer from inadequate facilities, antiquated equipment and shortages of medical supplies.

children.name: out of date
children.definition: out-of-date//ˌaʊt əv ˈdeɪt◂/  use this about books, maps etc that do not contain the most recent information, or about information that is no longer right because the facts have changed:
examples: lỗi thời,
▪ the map we had with us was completely out of date.
▪ an out-of-date guidebook

children.name: be stuck in a time-warp
children.definition: be stuck/caught in a time-warp/biː ˌstʌk, ˌkɔːt ɪn ə ˈtaɪm wɔːʳp/  if a place is stuck in a time-warp, it has not changed and seems the same as it was many years ago:
examples: bất chấp thời gian
▪ that restaurant is still stuck in some kind of late-seventies time-warp.
▪ the country had little contact with the outside world, and remained caught in something of a time-warp.

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfæʃənd◂/
examples: ▪ mr griffiths is a real old-fashioned teacher who still believes that learning lessons by heart is the best method.
▪ my dad was very old-fashioned and didn’t approve of me going to nightclubs with my friends.

children.name: be living in the past
children.definition: /biː ˌlɪvɪŋ ɪn ðə ˈpɑːstǁ-ˈpæst/  to think and behave as if life is still like it was when you were young, especially because you do not like the modern world:
examples: ▪ you’ve got to get over it, honey - you’ve got to stop living in the past.
▪ critics say buchanan is living in the past, and remind him that the 1950s was a time when women were shackled to the kitchen, and african-americans held back by discrimination.

children.name: behind the times
children.definition: /biː bɪˌhaɪnd ðə ˈtaɪmz/  apersonororganizationwho is behind the times, is old-fashioned because they have not changed while the world around them has changed :
examples: cổ hủ
▪ people in these parts tend to be way behind the times when it comes to issues such as women’s rights.
▪ once the giants of british retailing, they are now seen as being behind the times.

children.name: straitlaced/straightlaced
children.definition: /ˌstreɪtˈleɪst◂/  having a very strong, old-fashioned attitude tomoralbehaviour:
examples: khắt khe câu lệ, khổ hạnh
▪ my aunt’s very straitlaced - she’d be shocked if you mentioned sex.
▪ they lost touch with hermine after she married a very straightlaced lutheran minister, and disappeared from the social scene.

children.name: fuddy duddy
children.definition: /ˈfʌdi ˌdʌdi/ informalsomeone who you think is old-fashioned and boring because they disapprove of new ideas and are unwilling to change their attitudes:
examples: hủ lậu
▪ don’t be such a fuddy duddy!
▪ the election broadcast made the president look like a fuddy duddy with ridiculously old-fashioned ideas.
fuddy-duddy[adjective]
▪ she has some rather fuddy-duddy ideas about what is proper music.

children.name: old fogey
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfəʊgi/ informalsomeone, usually an old person, who you disapprove of because they prefer old-fashioned ideas and ways of doing things to modern ones:
examples: kẻ cổ hủ
▪ the old fogies all sit together and talk about the old days.
▪ this country is being run by a bunch of old fogies -- we need some fresh blood, people with initiative.

children.name: old guard
children.definition: /ˈəʊld ˌgɑːʳd/  a group of people with old-fashioned opinions, who have been in an organization or society for a long time and oppose anyone who wants to change things:
examples: vệ binh lão thành
▪ inevitably, the revolution is affecting the old guard much more than the rest of us.
▪ the party’s old guard have their own candidate for leader.

children.name: traditionalist
children.definition: /trəˈdɪʃənəlɪst, trəˈdɪʃənələst/  a person who believes that theold waysof doing things are the best, and who does not like modern methods or ideas:
examples: người nệ cổ, người theo chủ nghĩa truyền thống
▪ i’m something of a traditionalist myself, i’d much rather use pen and paper than a word-processor.
▪ there are still many traditionalists in the church who strongly oppose the idea of women priests.

children.name: medieval
children.definition: /ˌmediˈiːvəl◂ǁˌmiː-/  extremely old-fashioned and thereforeannoying:
examples: lạc hậu
▪ the plumbing in this house is medieval!
positively medievalvery medieval : cực kì lạc hậu
▪ this so-called accounting system is positively medieval.

children.name: out of the ark
children.definition: /ˌaʊt əv ði ˈɑːʳk/  britishinformalextremely old-fashioned:
examples: ▪ their washing machine looks like it came out of the ark.
▪ her views on social policy are embarrassing -- really out of the ark.

children.name: dinosaur
children.definition: /ˈdaɪnəsɔːʳ/ asystem, organization etcthat is very old-fashioned and large and cannot continue to exist in the modern world :
examples: khủng long
▪ the health service has become a dinosaur. it needs radical reform if it is to survive.
▪ the line-up includes a number of rock-n-roll dinosaurs who should have hung up their guitars long ago.

children.name: anachronism
children.definition: /əˈnækrənɪzəm/  something such as anorganizationorcustomthat belongs to a time in the past, and therefore appears very strange in the modern world:
examples: (tổ chức, phong tục) lỗi thời
▪ the harvest festival celebrations in the town are an anachronism since almost everyone who lives there nowadays works in an office.
anachronistic/əˌnækrəˈnɪstɪk◂/ [adjective]
▪ many people believe that the role of the royal family in britain is anachronistic.

children.name: archaic
children.definition: /ɑːʳˈkeɪ-ɪk/  use this aboutsomethingthat was used a long time ago but which is now considered too old-fashioned andneedsreplacing:
examples: cổ xưa
▪ the text was full of archaic spellings.
▪ the laws that decide who owns items discovered on an archeological exploration are ridiculously archaic.

children.name: dickensian
children.definition: /dɪˈkenziən/  buildings, conditions etc that are dickensian areextremelyold-fashioned and below acceptable standards, for example because they are dangerous or unhealthy:
examples: ▪ they were living in a dickensian apartment block without proper heating or running water.positively dickensian
▪ the working conditions in the factory were positively dickensian.

children.name: the dark ages
children.definition: /ðə ˈdɑːʳk ˌeɪdʒz/  use this to talk about a society, system, or way of thinking that is extremely old-fashioned, especially in its social attitudes:
examples: thời tối cổ
▪ huge amounts of aid will be needed if this society is ever to drag itself out of the dark ages.
▪ my brother still doesn’t like the idea of having a woman boss - he’s stuck in the dark ages!

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: /ˌəʊld ˈfæʃənd◂/  old-fashioned in a way thatremindsyou ofnicethingsin the past:
examples: cổ , không hợp thời trang
▪ the town has a lovely old-fashioned charm about it.
▪ he was a nice, old-fashioned gentleman who would hold open the door for you or offer to carry your bags.good old-fashioned
▪ good old-fashioned home cooking

children.name: quaint
children.definition: /kweɪnt/  old-fashioned and unusual, butattractiveandinteresting- use this about smallbuildingsorplaces, or aboutcustomsandbeliefs:
examples: cổ
▪ we stayed in a quaint little fishing village in cornwall.
▪ quaint country cottages
▪ stigler scoffed at the quaint idea of university as a place where a professor and a small group of students can sit in a study and discuss great thoughts.
